sentences.sentence: The second planet was inhabited( 居住着 ) by a conceited( 自负的 ) man.
“Ah! Ah! I am about to receive a visit from an admirer!” he exclaimed( 惊呼 ) from afar( 从远处 ), when he first saw the little prince coming.
For, to conceited( 自负的 ) men, all other men are admirers.
“Good morning,” said the little prince. “That is a queer( 奇怪的 ) hat you are wearing.”
“It is a hat for salutes( 敬礼 ),” the conceited( 自负的 ) man replied. “It is to raise in salute( 敬礼 ) when people acclaim( 为...喝彩 ) me. Unfortunately, nobody at all ever passes this way.”
“Yes?” said the little prince, who did not understand what the conceited( 自负的 ) man was talking about.
“Clap your hands, one against the other,” the conceited( 自负的 ) man now directed him.
The little prince clapped his hands.
The conceited( 自负的 ) man raised his hat in a modest salute( 敬礼 ).
“This is more entertaining( 有趣的 ) than the visit to the king,” the little prince said to himself.
And he began again to clap his hands, one against the other. The conceited( 自负的 ) man again raised his hat in salute( 敬礼 ).
After five minutes of this exercise the little prince grew tired of( 厌倦 ) the game’s monotony( 单调 ).
“And what should one do to make the hat come down?” he asked.
But the conceited( 自负的 ) man did not hear him.
Conceited( 自负的 ) people never hear anything but praise.
“Do you really admire me very much?” he demanded of the little prince.
“What does that mean—‘admire’?”
“To admire means that you regard me as the handsomest, the best-dressed, the richest, and the most intelligent man on this planet.”
“But you are the only man on your planet!”
“Do me this kindness. Admire me just the same.”
“I admire you,” said the little prince, shrugging his shoulders( 耸肩 ) slightly, “but what is there in that to interest you so much?”
And the little prince went away.
“The grown-ups( 成年人 ) are certainly very odd( 奇怪的 ),” he said to himself, as he continued on his journey.
The next planet was inhabited( 居住着 ) by a tippler( 酒鬼 ).
This was a very short visit, but it plunged( 使...陷入 ) the little prince into deep dejection( 沮丧 ).
“What are you doing there?” he said to the tippler( 酒鬼 ), whom he found settled down( 安静下来 ) in silence before a collection of( 一堆 ) empty bottles and also a collection of( 一堆 ) full bottles.
“I am drinking,” replied the tippler( 酒鬼 ), with a lugubrious( 阴郁的 ) air( 神态 ).
“Why are you drinking?” demanded the little prince.
“So that I may forget,” replied the tippler( 酒鬼 ).
“Forget what?” inquired( 询问 ) the little prince, who already was sorry for him.
“Forget that I am ashamed,” the tippler( 酒鬼 ) confessed( 承认 ), hanging his head.
“Ashamed of( 羞愧于... ) what?” insisted the little prince, who wanted to help him.
“Ashamed of( 羞愧于... ) drinking!” The tippler( 酒鬼 ) brought his speech to an end, and shut himself up in an impregnable( 坚不可摧的 ) silence.
And the little prince went away, puzzled( 困惑的 ).
“The grown-ups( 成年人 ) are certainly very, very odd( 奇怪的 ),” he said to himself, as he continued on his journey.
The fourth planet belonged to a businessman.
This man was so much occupied( 忙碌的 ) that he did not even raise his head at the little prince’s arrival.
“Good morning,” the little prince said to him. “Your cigarette has gone out( 熄灭 ).”
“Three and two make five. Five and seven make twelve. Twelve and three make fifteen. Good morning. Fifteen and seven make twenty-two.
Twenty-two and six make twenty-eight. I haven’t time to light it again. Twenty-six and five make thirty-one.
Phew( 啊 )!
Then that makes five-hundred-and-one-million, six-hundred-twenty-two-thousand, seven-hundred-thirty-one.”
“Five hundred million what?” asked the little prince.
“Eh? Are you still there? Five-hundred-and-one million—I can’t stop. . .
I have so much to do! I am concerned with( 关注... ) matters of consequence.
I don’t amuse( 使开心 ) myself with balderdash( 胡言乱语 ). Two and five make seven. . .”
“Five-hundred-and-one million what?” repeated the little prince, who never in his life had let go of a question once he had asked it.
The businessman raised his head.
“During the fifty-four years that I have inhabited( 居住 ) this planet, I have been disturbed( 被打扰 ) only three times.
The first time was twenty-two years ago, when some giddy( 发狂的 ) goose fell from goodness knows where.
He made the most frightful noise that resounded( 回响 ) all over the place, and I made four mistakes in my addition( 加法 ).
The second time, eleven years ago, I was disturbed( 被打扰 ) by an attack of rheumatism( 风湿病 ). I don’t get enough exercise. I have no time for loafing.
The third time—well, this is it! I was saying, then, five-hundred-and-one millions—”
“Millions of what?”
The businessman suddenly realized that there was no hope of being left in peace until he answered this question.
“Millions of those little objects,” he said, “which one sometimes sees in the sky.”
“Flies?”
“Oh, no. Little glittering( 闪闪发光的 ) objects.”
“Bees?”
“Oh, no. Little golden objects that set lazy men to idle dreaming( 空想 ). As for me, I am concerned with matters of consequence.
There is no time for idle dreaming( 空想 ) in my life.”
“Ah! You mean the stars?”
“Yes, that’s it. The stars.”
“And what do you do with five-hundred millions of stars?”
“Five-hundred-and-one million, six-hundred-twenty-two thousand, seven-hundred-thirty-one.
I am concerned with matters of consequence: I am accurate( 精确的 ).”
“And what do you do with these stars?”
“What do I do with them?”
“Yes.”
“Nothing. I own them.”
“You own the stars?”
“Yes.”
“But I have already seen a king who—”
“Kings do not own, they reign over( 统治 ). It is a very different matter.”
“And what good does it do you to own the stars?”
“It does me the good of making me rich.”
“And what good does it do you to be rich?”
“It makes it possible for me to buy more stars, if any are ever discovered.”
“This man,” the little prince said to himself, “reasons a little like my poor tippler( 酒鬼 ) . . .”
Nevertheless, he still had some more questions.
“How is it possible for one to own the stars?”
“To whom do they belong?” the businessman retorted( 反驳 ), peevishly( 气恼地 ).
“I don’t know. To nobody.”
“Then they belong to( 属于 ) me, because I was the first person to think of it.”
“Is that all that is necessary?”
“Certainly. When you find a diamond that belongs to( 属于 ) nobody, it is yours. When you discover an island that belongs to( 属于 ) nobody, it is yours.
When you get an idea before anyone else, you take out( 获得... ) a patent( 专利权 ) on it: it is yours.
So with me: I own the stars, because nobody else before me ever thought of owning them.”
“Yes, that is true,” said the little prince. “And what do you do with them?”
“I administer( 管理 ) them,” replied the businessman. “I count them and recount( 重新清点 ) them. It is difficult. But I am a man who is naturally interested in matters of consequence.”
The little prince was still not satisfied.
“If I owned a silk scarf,” he said, “I could put it around my neck and take it away with me. If I owned a flower, I could pluck( 摘取 ) that flower and take it away with me.
But you cannot pluck( 摘取 ) the stars from heaven . . .”
“No. But I can put them in the bank.”
“Whatever does that mean?”
“That means that I write the number of my stars on a little paper. And then I put this paper in a drawer and lock it with a key.”
“And that is all?”
“That is enough,” said the businessman.
“It is entertaining( 有趣的 ),” thought the little prince. “It is rather poetic. But it is of no great consequence.”
On matters of consequence, the little prince had ideas which were very different from those of the grown-ups( 成年人 ).
“I myself own a flower,” he continued his conversation with the businessman, “which I water every day.
I own three volcanoes( 火山 ), which I clean out every week (for I also clean out( 打扫 ) the one that is extinct( 不再活跃的 ); one never knows).
It is of some use to my volcanoes( 火山 ), and it is of some use to my flower, that I own them. But you are of no use to the stars . . .”
The businessman opened his mouth, but he found nothing to say in answer.
And the little prince went away.
“The grown-ups( 成年人 ) are certainly altogether extraordinary,” he said simply, talking to himself as he continued on his journey.

article_info.previous: 小王子开始了他的旅程，他拜访的第一颗行星只有一个人居住，而这个人自封为该行星的王。
article_info.share_words: “I could put it around my neck and take it away with me. If I owned a flower, I could pluck that flower and take it away with me. But you cannot pluck the stars from heaven . . .”

question.cn: 自负的人的帽子是拿来做什么用的？
question.en: What was the use of the conceited man's hat?

options.en: It was used to play games.

analysis: 原文提到：“It is a hat for salutes,” the conceited man replied. “It is to raise in salute when people acclaim me. Unfortunately, nobody at all ever passes this way.” 所以答案为B。

question.cn: 当小王子第一次遇见商人的时候，商人在干什么？
question.en: What was the businessman doing when the little prince first met him?

options.en: He was raising his hat for salutes.

analysis: 原文提到：This man was so much occupied that he did not even raise his head at the little prince’s arrival.“Three and two make five. Five and seven make twelve. Twelve and three make fifteen. Good morning. Fifteen and seven make twenty-two.  所以答案为A。

原文中商人回答小王子的提问，提到：“Oh, no. Little golden objects that set lazy men to idle dreaming. As for me, I am concerned with matters of consequence. There is no time for idle dreaming in my life.”“Ah! You mean the stars?” 所以答案为C。

question.cn: 根据商人的说法，他怎么对待星星？
question.en: According to the businessman, what did he do with the stars?

options.en: He locked them in a drawer.

analysis: 原文提到：“I administer them,” replied the businessman. “I count them and recount them. It is difficult. But I am a man who is naturally interested in matters of consequence.” 所以答案为C。
